so good morning everyone well it's great to have you all here today this is absolutely our most favorite

your organization's and to move quickly and I'm constantly amazed and inspired
by all the builders I meet across the UK public sector their desire and their
passion and what they're able to achieve on a dress and so it's probably no
surprise that our customer base is is growing we have millions of customers active customers and what we mean by an
active customer is an on Amazon entity that's used the eight abreast platform in the last 30 days and across all areas
so whether it be startups or enterprises and closer to home in the UK we have
over a hundred thousand customers supported by over a hundred partners and many of those partners are here today
and so you can go and speak to them in the exhibition space we've provided over 1300 individual training days for our
customers focused on cloud from everything from architecting to DevOps to technical essentials
and these customers are recognizing some of the benefits of a de Bresse and some
of the services and innovation that's happening which I'll come on to a little bit but one which is deployed
geographically across the world so we now have 18 region core regions across
the globe and 54 availability zones which is which is ever-increasing and so
for all of those of you that aren't familiar a region for us is think of it as a compliance zone if you store your
data in a specific region it won't leave there unless you choose to do so and then within each region we have multiple
availability zones and availability zones have their own risk and compliance regime and an availability zone has at
least once many physical data centers here in a mirror we have we now have
five sorry four regions that have launched so we have our Dublin region our London region or Frankfurt region in
our Paris region and we've also pre announced both our Stockholm and Bahrain region in the UK and Ireland we have our
long-standing Dublin region and obviously very excited about the launch
of our London region which happened in December 2016 six availability zones across both of
those regions and in fact London actually launched with two availability zones but we heard from our customers
that they're really like really benefit from the third availability zone so we launched that third availability zone in
London at the beginning of the year in January 2018 at the heart of the London
region was we heard from customers that they had workloads with data sovereignty
requirements they wanted to have on UK Shores but we also had commercial
customers and financial services customers who wanted low latency access to an a diverse capability and hence the
London region was born so we're expanding our services and features that
are a rapid clip and in fact in 2017 we launched over 1,400 services and new
features alone and these sort of features and capabilities are ready and
available for our public sector custom to use in order to drive their mission forward and the barrier to entry to
these types of services and features is extremely low it's really simple to get up and running and to start
experimenting and we see customers from across the spectrum benefiting from this
pace of innovation because fundamentally it creates a set of unique advantages
but its advantages that quickly become the new normal so customers and Pete
developers and builders will start expecting this type of functionality they'll look start expecting to be able
to use things like artificial intelligence start expecting to be able to use GPUs or FPGAs so it becomes a new
new normal but it's not just the features and functionality it's a set of freedoms that you get from this type of
capability so you think about freedoms you think about things like service computing with lambda or our newly
announced serve list databases with serverless Aurora that we announced re-invent late last year so you not only
unshackled from the physical infrastructure but you don't even need to worry about the virtual compute infrastructure either you can just
consume you can run function so you can consume databases and pay for what you use so you come free to use this type
capability unshackle from physical infrastructure but also from old-guard technology provider
Odegard technology providers ultimately allowing you to reduce your technical debt and thrive so a couple of examples
of customers that using this type of technology in our Brussels Summit recently we had a company called skin
vision and they talked about a platform they built and ultimately you know one
in five paper will get skin cancer in their lifetime and they built a platform that enables you to take a foetus an app
you can download take a photo of skin a skin Admiral Mullen ality and upload it to
the cloud and it uses machine learning to make predictions on whether that is something that should be high risk and
should be say you should scan see a dermatology professional or something that you don't need to worry about so
much and so cloud has really changed their ability to deliver this type of functionality and it takes away a lot of
the heavy lifting around things that Maine may or may not be a problem another area that we're hearing a lot
about at the moment is around voice technology and this is especially you know prevalent in local government and
Tricia or comments or some of this later on but also in healthcare and this is aligned with the recent NHS cloud
guidance and it's it's using things like Alexa to be able to provide
population-wide education and so we had organizations like public health England who have been able to create Alexa
skills and one of those Alexa skills is for new mothers called my breastfeeding friends so voice is becoming really
really important and so with that in mind I'm delighted to work on the stage chief deputy law officer for an HHS
Business Services Authority Darren Curie to talk about their experience and journey through cloud

thank you so yeah we're going to talk about how we used Amazon Connect in our
call center specifically for our European health insurance card service and gone just a little bit about who the
NHS business services authority are not a lot of people may have heard of us as
an organization but most people will have used one of our services at some point so we have three main server

elements NHS dental services aren't scanning services we process 30 million
prescription forms every month pay pharmacists so each year we do with nine
billion pounds worth of drug money and it just works no not illegal drugs legal drugs and it

a largest pension scheme in Europe and in the son of the area where I'm going to talk about is sets and services so
they're all of our public facing services that people access and specifically they're the European health
insurance card so there's currently 26 million European health insurance cards out there in the
population that we issue so it's when you go abroad and our contact under services deal with contact around that
so in contact on earth just to give a sense of scale we have four hundred and
fifty contact centre peers who deal with just short of five million contacts per
year and based in obviously Newcastle if you didn't tell of that we do have a
level or voice automation currently on that platform which deals with around about 300,000 calls that is a non
intelligent voice automation so takes words and populates forms in the backend to process and application forms we have
two and a half million hits to our website each year on frequently asked questions one of the
challenges ironically that we had as we have a really low complaint rate so the
services we deliver are really well received with our user group and we have
a year-on-year increase so over the last three years we've seen contacts to our contact center increase by 25% which is
about a million contacts so we've grown quite a lot we also need to scale our
services so we offer services are they an instant requirement of people like
public health England if there's something going on in the wider NHS service why we choose to use AWS Connect
so number one them user experience that's that's why we went with with
Connect we wanted to provide a seamless experience for our users where users
could access the service at a time which is convenient to them so our current call center operates a fairly
traditional time frame of 8:00 in the morning until about 6:00 in the evening and some Saturday working as well for
some services but not 24/7 on those times I kind of not ideal for our user
needs now people want to be able to access the services at a time which is suitable to those those individuals we
wanted to enable our contacts and operators to be able to deal with the users that required more support so
taking them off task for dealing with relatively straightforward queries so
the European health insurance cards a really good example we get a lot of quick queries of people forwarding and
asking can I use European health insurance card in France can I use it in Germany there very simple yes/no answers
but contacting the contact centres taking that operator off service where they could be helping someone with the sister
digital needs or more complex queries in our pension service for example and we
needed to be scalable so again European health insurance card a really good example of this so over the summer
months it spiked massive for all if someone like Marc Louis
decides to remind everybody that they need to European health insurance card to go abroad we get massive spike in our
call centers and and so we need to be able to grow the platform quickly deal with that and then finally was it cost
savings so we're on traditional on-premise infrastructure it's not
efficient to have that kind of scale of infrastructure to deal with the course
what we set out to do kind of iterative we looked and took the approach to fail
fast so we want to implement something quickly see if it worked and if it didn't work just kind of let it go if it

increased the school we went a 24/7 operating and then conclude the park but
this is probably the bit that people are most interested in what were the results of doing this and a bit that I was most
impressed in was two weeks two weeks bill time from initial call with our
cloud brokerage partners or arcus global where we worked with on this piece of work on the AWS team we spent two weeks
building and that wasn't really us doing much building that was the course and
management team they worked with the technical team we allocated to
individuals who knew the European health insurance card so these were business users to talk about what the types of
queries are we implemented after two weeks an initial proof of concept and
then we had to serve this operational for three three weeks and went 24/7 for the last five days but was it successful
so over that time so we did pick a time when European health insurance wasn't kind of on everyone's radar it was round
about November time so it wasn't huge numbers but these numbers are scalable
across the year they would work and so we received just short of 11,000 calls over the three weeks and of that 4,300
calls were fully resolved by the lacs so that's a 40% success rate on that so
that's two weeks of work to get a 40 percent reduction in call volume or 40
percent customer satisfaction so it was very successful from our point do 5,000
calls were transferred to operators that's not that Lex didn't provide information select did provide some
information on that but we didn't integrate with back-end services so it still dropped out to an operator to
complete the end of that transaction another only 663 calls dropped out from
Lex so of 10,000 calls 11,000 660 so he dropped out so it's a really successful
trial for us kind of to do that in the
old way would have taken probably four or six months so in two weeks and week
one we got 38% so it was you know we got a really high percentage of the 40
within one week of the service going live over 75% of the calls were handled
within six minutes the contacts and seen a 26% reduction to operators so that was
enabling those guys to deal with the more important calls and Lex answered on
average three point eight question so a question of kind of use it in France
how do I apply is kind of follow-up so for questions what next we're planning to roll it out

worldwide public sector marketing Trisha Trisha Davis Moffitt [Music]
[Applause] thank you good morning everybody I'm so
excited to see you here this is not my first time at the London summit in fact
I was here the first time we had a public sector track several years ago and it was a very tiny little room so
I'm excited to see all of you here and I'm very excited about the incredible
innovations that I'm seeing come out of public sector customers across the UK
and Europe so today I want to talk a little bit about our our group of
companies that we're working with who are helping us to innovate so this
technology revolution which we really see as the largest technology shift of
our lifetimes is not just about Amazon and what AWS is doing this is about the
broader set of customers and partners who are helping to make change for our
public sector customers so we have built the AWS partner Network which has tens
of thousands of APN partners from across the globe and we are adding more all the
time and if any of you are not partners or you're from a company that's considering
partnering with us it really is quite easy to become a partner we welcome new
partners all the time into that network so I encourage you to take that step if
you are considering becoming a partner we now have a hundred and 60 public sector partners across Europe the Middle
East and Africa and that includes both consulting partners and technical
partners who have proven expertise across industries like government education and healthcare and nonprofits
and we know that this is especially important in the public sector because we know that developers and builders are
at a premium in schools in agencies in nonprofit organizations so you may not
have the people on staff to help actually get the the application built that you need so
we're very cognizant of the fact that we rely on these partners these independent
software vendors to actually build solutions that will work for the public sector so the breadth of our partner
community is accelerating our customers innovation in the cloud and one of the
things that I love about our services is that you I'm sure you know about how
easy it is to scale and to pay for only what you're using on storage and compute
but it's also that's also the case for applications that you may be used to
using so it in the marketplace you can actually with just a few clicks access
any of the applications that you're used to using in an on-premise environment and you pay only for the licenses you're
using at the time that you're using them only for the volume of work that's happening on those on those technologies
and more than 160 thousand active customers are using software from the
AWS marketplace so overall the marketplace offers more than four thousand software listings
from across 1280 independent software vendors so if you haven't yet taking a
look at that I do encourage you to take a look at the all of the different offerings that are available through the
marketplace okay so in Amazon we call
ourselves customer obsessed that we we try to be the most customer obsessed company on the planet and in the public
sector we really consider ourselves citizen obsessed we are obsessed with
making things better for citizens and with helping you to make things better for your citizens if you think about how
citizens are engaging in the world just as human beings and consumers they
expect access to all the information that they need if they expect it on their mobile devices they expect it to
be easy they expect to be able to get what they need when they need and that's only accelerating for students for
citizens for people who are trying to access nonprofits the harder that you make it the less likely it is that they will
engage with you that they'll do the things that they need to do we know that and so that's why we're very excited to
help the public sector to really innovate and keep pace with the commercial environment one of our
earliest adopters of technology here in in the UK was Transport for London and I
imagine all of you probably engaged with Transport for London on your way here today I certainly did yesterday on my
way from Heathrow and I think that the way that they have really made information accessible to people when
they need it in the right format has been a real leap forward for them and it
has helped them to manage their costs and be more efficient as they've moved forward they've also now really
innovated on making their data open and helping to provide more innovation
opportunities for others who surround them and they are managing 24 million
journeys on on their platform all the time so they open they are really are a
leader in innovation in the public sector in addition you know you think
okay well that's a big city you know how can I compete with that we have we have smaller cities and local governments
across the world who are really taking advantage of our innovation as well and the opportunities Peterborough City
Council is one of my favorites there there are another winner of the city on a cloud challenge which I'll talk to you
about in a minute but they are using AWS as a central hub to pull together all of
the feeds and all of the data that's coming in from weather stations from
smart energy meters from sensors in people's homes and in libraries to really try to become a leader in being a
smart city and Aylesbury Vale District Council they originally engaged with us
just to be able to scale their websites but since then they have adopted more advanced services and they're now using
machine learning and something that we're seeing many local governments do is they're using Alexa to
engage with their citizens so that the citizens can actually find out when is my when is my rubbish pickup when you
know where can I go to update my drivers license things like that so they they're able to access those services when and
where they need you so that's another example of just really being where the citizen needs the information and when
to help them access the government in a much more scalable and efficient way so
I mentioned earlier the city on a cloud innovation challenge which several of the UK customers have actually won and
that competition is open right now it's this is in the fourth year of the
competition and actually one of our first winners was the London City Airport we've had winners from from
across the UK and Europe if you would like to submit a nomination I encourage
you all to do that the competition actually closes this Friday but it's quite simple to submit a nomination and
there are several categories so one of the categories is if you are already
using AWS and you have something interesting that you'd like to share with other local governments you can
submit for the best practices award and that really has been a great help to
many of our local government customers who are in local or regional governments to help them see what's possible so I
encourage you if you're using us already to submit what it is that you're doing we'd love to recognize you
also if you're a partner if you're one of those independent software vendors who is actually creating software
applications that are useful to local governments where as a partner in innovation award that's available for
those companies then if you have not yet started and you have an idea and you're
you're looking at this stuff and you're saying gosh I really wish I could implement that service you can put in
for the dream big award and we've had a number of cities large and small who have won that those dream big awards and
that will provide you with credits to actually make your dream a reality and as you saw from the NHS example that
typical of the kinds of things that that we're able to do with a pilot project it doesn't take very long to get something
up and running and see if it's going to work and then we also have a new category this year which is the we power
tech award and that is for services or innovations that will help reach
underrepresented populations so I encourage you nonprofit organizations educational institutions or government
entities who would like to submit for that so and you can win we will be
announcing our winners at the public sector summit in Washington DC in June
and you can win up to $50,000 u.s. in AWS credits okay
so innovation it doesn't just take companies I talked about the companies that are helping to innovate with us and
certainly what what we're doing Chris talked about all the innovations that we brought to market last year but all that
innovation requires people there have to be people who know how to make use of
the technology and this is one of the big challenges that we are trying to take on right now we have to build a
pipeline of cloud talent without that all of this innovation will go to waste
and the need is urgent so the European Commission reports that more than
350,000 information communications and technology positions are open and not
being filled across Europe and tens of thousands of those are here in the UK and with historically low unemployment
in the UK there are there are so many you know requirements and this is
stopping our governments our educational institutions our nonprofits from moving
forward because they can't find the right talent so what are we going to do about that so we have programs that are
helping to create access to cloud skills we believe that we have a role to play
in closing this skills gap and that's why we've developed these programs and the programs are really meant to engage
people of all backgrounds so that includes retired military and there's
educators young students women and others who have been underrepresented in
technology and in fact we're already seeing results so the restart program
was really geared to helping people start a new career in technology here in
the UK and 68% have graduated to on-the-job training and 63% have
graduated to job placement from that program we power tech as I mentioned before is a program that really is meant
to help showcase women and underrepresented minorities who are succeeding in technology but also to
bring training to people who have not seen themselves as technologists in the
past the AWS Academy brings very practical cloud training into
universities and AWS educate is a program that is meant for students an
AWS educate is reaching even more students with cloud curriculum and we
are very happy to announce that it's now available in not only English but also
in Spanish and Portuguese and students can choose from multiple pathways to learn cloud skills and the the training
that's available online through a degree us educate which is a free program available to anyone who has enrolled
part-time full-time you know continuing education in any kind of higher
education and also actually now it's available to students who are 16 and
above in across Europe and the UK and the pathways are meant to be very
focused on actual jobs that you could do using cloud skills so they really gear
you to what do you want that career to look like and it gives you a pathway to
learn those skills very practical training and then students can also apply for jobs on the AWS job board it
helps them package up the projects that they do through the program and submit those in those job applications hundreds
of thousands of students and 1,500 institutions worldwide already participate in AWS educate and if you
know a student or a university who you could bring into the program please we encourage you and we often have
people say well what's the catch why is that why are you guys doing this for free we're doing it for free because we need these people to be trained we need
that those cloud skills to be out there in the market we recently announced that
we are also committed to reaching a hundred thousand people across Europe
with access to cloud training so together with the programs that I just mentioned individuals who are seeking
digital skills also have access to events like Awesome days that provide
practical training for people who really want to get up to speed in person trainings with AWS solution architects
and access to our free digital training platform so at reinvent last year our training and certification team released
a range of free training options that are available through our website so if
you haven't seen that yet I do encourage you to take a look at it so you can visit our solutions Expo down downstairs
or talk to account an account manager to find out how you can take advantage of these opportunities beyond the tech
talent pipeline we also know that as I mentioned those independent software vendors the software vendors are a very
important part of our ecosystem but the education technology of innovators are
very important for education innovations they're happening and we know that that's a tough place to
be being a start-up trying to build new solutions for education so we are here
to support those companies that are trying to build new solutions to help help educators innovate and this is a
program that is a community for education technology companies and the benefits are give them cloud credits it
also gives them customized training a community of others who have been in this space and who are trying to succeed
in in the same space technical support and joint marketing opportunities to
help them spread the word about what they're doing
another another thing that we're doing to expand in in Europe and the UK is to
build thought leadership and best practices throughout the region so we recently announced that our Brussels
summit last month that the AWS Institute is now available in Europe and this is a
forum where we're helping those who are leading major public sector organisations who have something they're
trying to accomplish but they have not really envisioned how technology could help so for instance we
have we have mayor's who in the in the US who are trying to solve homelessness and they are trying to envision you know
what could technology have to do with that so we're working with people who are trying to solve problems that are
not immediately obvious that they could be solved through technology and to bring them together to talk with public
sector leaders to build policies and to help to innovate we held our first
Europe roundtable at our Brussels summit last month on AI for leaders and
democratizing access to AI and we're excited that we'll be hosting future roundtables here in the UK okay so with
that I'm very happy to introduce our next speaker and Heidi Fraser Krauss the chief
information officer from University of York was recognized last year as CIO of
the year for computing women in technology Awards so please welcome to
the stage Heidi Fraser Cross
hello everybody so first of all a word of warning if somebody from AWS says to
you could you take part in a panel say no because that is their way in to get
you to give a keynote speech that's the technique so just a word of warning so
I'm going to talk a little bit about AWS and how we're using cloud at the
University of York it's worth saying that we're on the beginning of the journey that mythical journey and but
I'll share with you and our thoughts and experiences but first of all a little bit about the higher education sector so
there's been some big numbers and talked about here from the NHS 30 million prescriptions a month and we can't quite
compete with that however in the UK there are about 2.2 million students and in terms of
contribution to the UK economy latest figures are around 73 billion in terms
of contribution higher education is a big and complicated sector so there's
about 168 providers of various shapes and sizes in the UK and we are obviously
national and international we're also highly regulated so you may have seen in
the press we have a new regulator the office for students and they basically want quite properly higher education
institutions to provide education that's cost effective that is fit for purpose
and of high quality standard and then also make sure that we include everybody
in that offering so they're very very keen that we make sure so some of the comments that were made earlier around
everybody getting involved in education and so we're actually regulated to provide that now University of York if I
can talk a little bit about us and we're a smallish University turnover of about 350 million and 18,000 students we are
extremely diverse as a university so we have people from all sorts of different
backgrounds and all sorts of nationalities so about 140 countries we reckon study at the
University and all sorts of economic socio-economic backgrounds our principles of establishment were around
equality and diversity and I'm very proud to be part of that and to continue that going on we also are something called a Russell
group University which means we're part of an elite group of 24 and we're focused on research and we do research
on everything everything from plasma physics to post-war reconstruction and
again very proud of that sort of thing if I talk a little bit about technology and we just have a look at the student
view so for those of you are familiar with this this is Maslow's hierarchy of needs the bottom layer is physiological
needs like food shelter and water and students have put Wi-Fi below that one
and I have to say that from my experience of dealing with students and my office is actually in the library in
York this is exactly right students depend on technology like nothing else
now sure those of you our parents will know that Wi-Fi is it but more seriously
students depend on technology for their learning and so we use technology all the time now in delivery and we also use
it to support their learning so I was saying about em taking students in from all different backgrounds one of the
things we also have to do as far as the regulator's concerned is make sure we keep those students and ensure that they
have a career at the other end and we use technology to monitor their performance and support them along the
line for staff obviously we also need to provide high quality facilities and that
is a differentiator for students some of these things is hygiene the staff it's a differentiator so if we're talking about
plasma physics the ability for me to be able to provide facilities quickly and cheaply to plasma physicists is a
differentiator ok so why would I be interested in the cloud I'm sorry this
is a little bit cheesy I wanted to say key drivers and these were the only things I
could try to represent this in a different way you know you get those pictures where you're trying to guess a phrase so this
is what I was trying to do here so what my key drivers so I think the first thing I don't have a burning platform in
terms of technology I've got two good data centers fairly well equipped there however what I believe and is I think
obvious probably to everybody in this room that cloud is a paradigm shift that
ain't going away you can't stick your fingers in your ears and say no no not going to happen you have to engage with
it so we're engaging with it because we feel that we absolutely have to we want
to be on the right side of that change and what I'm interested in is having staff who are able to engage in all the
excitement so the stuff that's just been talked about is just magical and I want staff at the University of York my staff
to understand the benefits and be able to make use of those facilities and
technologies and I've also got to deliver a digital strategy for the University at this moment in time I'm
not entirely sure what a digital strategy is but I do know that the cloud will be part of it other services I want
to be able to provide to academic staff things like GP you to be able to spin up
a large number of GPUs in the cloud it's very expensive for me in fact they're prohibitively expensive in time and cost
to be able to do that so I want to be able to leverage these things and then things like service technology to stop
us doing that ground all of those things that you will probably be interested in your own businesses are of interest to
me but at the top its that move it's that skillset and mindset change okay
and given that we're fairly new on this journey what are my challenges I think
the first challenge is the skill piece actually it's having a way of supporting
staff encouraging them to develop into this different way of thinking Amazon
have been so AWS have been extremely supportive on that we've had workshops on-site but it is a real it's one of
those things that you have to keep going out and keep convincing some people were very threatened by this in the
getting and they're moving towards seeing what the advantages are now so
that's one challenge another challenge is complexity this is really complicated
stuff it's not just something people will tell you it's plug and play and I
know people were saying they'd set up in very short paces spaces of time but there is a lot of thought needs to go
into these things and giving them having the time to architect things think all of that through that complexity piece is
is a challenge and I also think there's a again this plug and play idea I think
you're not gonna move vendor you're not gonna move you're going to be locked in
to some degree with these providers given the complexity and therefore you need the challenges to make the right
choice of partner to decide who you want to work with because I don't think this is going to be something that you move
every year or so and having said all of that oh sorry one more thing on
challenge is price and not as in how much it costs but how to manage price
how to manage the complexity of the pricing and again AWS have been very supportive with us but that's something
